And this is the fact, just as each person uses his fortune, so does he surpass others, and forthwith we all pronounce him wise. When we learn that the counsels of any person have turned out well, we declare that he is a prudent man; but that he is a fool who is unsuccessful. In our folly we know not how much we are mistaken, when we eagerly wish anything to be given to us; as though we ourselves could possibly know what is for our advantage. We lose what is certain, while we are seeking what is uncertain. And this comes to pass, amid labours and amid sorrow, that death meanwhile comes creeping on. But there's enough now of philosophizing; I have been talking too long, and at too great length. Immortal Gods! my lie was not dear at its weight in double-distilled gold, which I just now trumped up here on the spur of the moment, when I said that I belonged to the procurer. Now, through this letter shall I deceive three persons--my master, and the procurer, and him who gave me this letter. Excellent! another thing as well has happened, that I wished for: see, Calidorus is coming; he is bringing some one with him, I know not whom. Stands apart.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: The sweets and the bitters, all have I disclosed to you. You know my love, you know my difficulty, you know my poverty.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I well remember all; do you only let me know what you want me to do.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: Pseudolus has directed me thus, that I should bring to him some bold and zealous person.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You observe your directions well; for you bring him one both friendly and zealous. But this Pseudolus is a stranger to me.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: He is a very clever fellow--he is my contriver. He said that he would effect those things for me that I have told you of.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: apart. I'll address this person in a very lofty strain.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: Whose voice is it that's heard here?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Oh! thee, sovereign lord, thee, oh! thee do I address who dost rule over Pseudolus: thee do I seek, to impart to thee delights thrice three, threefold, acquired by three contrivances, obtained over three persons through craftiness and through subtlety, which in this very little sealed packet I have brought unto youI have brought unto you: The note of interrogation at the end of this passage, as found in Ritschel's Edition, seems to be out of place.. Holds up the letter.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: That's the fellow; how the hang-dog does bluster just like a tragedian.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Advance a step on thy side towards me. Boldly stretch forth thine arm for greeting.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: taking his hand. Tell me, Pseudolus, whether, as Hope or as Safety, must I greet you?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Why both.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: As both I greet you. But what has been done? Why are you silent? I have carried this person here. Pointing to CHARINUS.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: How? Carried him here?

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: Brought, I meant to say.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Who's this person?

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: Charinus.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Well done; I return him thanksReturn him thanks: xu/rin tou/tw| poiw\. He speaks in Greek for the purpose of punning on the name of Charinus in the word xa/rin, "thanks." then.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Will you then boldly enjoin me what it is necessary to do?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: My thanks, so far. May it be well with you, Charinus; I don't like that we should be troublesome to you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You, troublesome to me? Now, really, that's troublesome.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Well, then, wait a moment. Takes the letter out from under his dress.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: This letter have I just now intercepted, and the token.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: Token? What token?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: The one that was brought just now from the Captain. His servant, who was bringing it, with five mineæ of silver, who came to fetch your mistress hence, him I have just now bamboozled.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: For the sake of these Spectators the play is being performed; they know, who were present here; you I'll tell at another time.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: What are we to do then?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: You shall this day embrace your mistress at liberty.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: What, I?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: You yourself.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Your own self, I say, if indeed this head shall exist so long; if you'll only quickly find me out a man.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Of what description?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: A cunning, crafty and clever one, who, when he has once taken hold of the beginning, may by his own ingenuity still hold fast upon what it behoves him to do; one, too, who has not often been seen here.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: If he is a slave, does that matter at all?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Why, I'd much rather have him than a free man.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I think that I'm able to procure for you a cunning and clever fellow, that has lately come to my father from CarystusFrom Carystus: This was a city of Eubœa, opposite the Isle of Andros., and hasn't as yet gone anywhere out the house, and who never visited Athens before yesterday.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: You assist in right earnest. But I have need to borrow five minæ of silver, which I shall repay this day, for his father pointing to CALIDORUS owes it me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'll lend it; don't seek it anywhere else.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: O, how convenient a person for me. I have need of a scarf as well, a sword, and a broad-brimmed hat.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I can provide them from my house.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Immortal Gods! surely this is not Charinus for me, but Abundance. But this servant, who is come here from Carystus, is there anything in him?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Plenty of the stinking goatThe stinking goat: He cannot resist the temptation of a pun, though a somewhat unsavoury one. Pseudolus asks if this servant of Charinus is at all sharp. "Quid sapit?" The same words also admit of the meaning, "does he smell of anything?" On which Charinus gives him answer, as though the question had been put in the latter sense, "Yes, of the goat under the arm- pits." The Romans, who were fond of giving a name to everything, whether it was worth it or not, called the strong smell produced by the glands of the arm-pits by the name of "hircus," "the goat," by reason of the rank smell of that animal. in him.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: It befits the fellow, then, to have a tunic with long sleevesTunic with long sleeves: On this dirty answer being given him, Pesudolus says, "Well, then, he must have an under-garment with long sleeves," "manuleata tunica," in order to suppress the offensive smell. The use of the long-sleeved tunic was considered to denote great effeminacy. Has the chap anything sharpAnything sharp: "Ecquid aceti." Literally, "any vinegar." This word sometimes signifies "caustic wit" or "raillery" Here it denotes "natural shrewdness. in his breast?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Aye, of the very sharpest.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: But if it is necessary for him to draw forth what is sweet from the same place, has he aught of that?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Do you ask that He has wine of myrrh, sweet raisin wine, spice wineRaisin wine, spice wine: "Passum" was wine made from grapes dried in the sun. "Defrutum" was new wine boiled down to one-half with herbs and spices to make it keep. honey wine, sweets of every sort. Why, he once began to set up a hot liquor-shop in his breast.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Bravissi o! Why, Charinus, you beat me cleverlyYou beat me cleverly: "Lamberas." The verb "lambero" generally signifies "to tear in pieces." at my own game. But what am I to say is the name of this servant?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Simmia.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: In a difficulty, does he understand how to twirl about?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: A whirlwindA whirlwind: "Turbo" may mean either a "spinning-" or "whipping-top," or a "whirlwind," here. is not so ready as he.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Is he shrewd at all?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: In mischievous tricksIn mischievous tricks: "Argutus," as an adjective, signifies "clever," "shrewd." As the past participle of the verb "arguo," it means "accused." Pseudolus asks if he is "shrewd," "argutus" to which the other answers evasively, "O yes (he has been accused," "argutus"), "of mischievous tricks very often." very often.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: How, when he's caught in the fact?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: He's a very eel; he slips out.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Is this fellow an experienced one?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: A public ordinanceA public ordinance: The "plebiscita" among the Romans were the public ordinances, which were proposed by the Tribunes at the "Comitia Tributa" of the people. He puns upon the resemblance of the word "scitus," which means "knowing," and "scitum" signifying "an ordinance." Is he "scitus," "knowing?" "O yes, a public ordinance" "scitum," 'is not more knowing," "scitus," "than he is" is not more experienced.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: He is a suitable person, according to what I hear you say.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Aye, and from this you may know it. When he looks at you he'll tell, of his own accord, what it is you want with him. But what are you about to do?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: I'll tell you. When I've dressed up my man, I intend to make him become the pretended servant of the Captain; let him take this token to the procurer, with five minæ of silver. There's the whole plot for you. As for the rest, in what way he is to do each thing, I'll instruct himself.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: Why, therefore, do we stand here then?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Bring the fellow to me just now, dressed out with all his accoutrements, to Æschinus, the banker's. But make all haste.

sp.speaker: CALIDORUS
sp.p: We'll be there before you.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Get you gone there quickly. CALIDORUS and CHARINUS go into SIMO'S house. Whatever before was uncertain or doubtful in my mind, is now clear-now fined to the dregs; my heart has now an open path. All my legions will I lead forth under their standards with happy omenWith happy omen: "Ave sinistrâ" Literally, "with a bird on the left hand." This was considered to be a fatvorable omen. with favorable auspices, and to my heart's content. I have a certainty that I can rout my enemies. Now will I go to the Forum, and load Simmia with my instructions what he is to do, that he may not be tripping at all, and that he may cleverly lay the train for this plot. Soon now shall I cause the town of this procurer to be carried by storm. (Exit.)

div2.stage: Enter a BOY from the house of BALLIO.

sp.speaker: A BOY
sp.p: On that Boy on whom the Gods bestow servitude under a procurer, when they add a base occupation as well, assuredly do they, so far as I now understand in my mind, bestow upon him a great misfortune and miseries manifold. Just as this servitude has turned out to me, where I am set over duties great and small; nor am I able to find any admirer to love me, so that at length I might be fitted out in a little better guise. Now this day is the birthday of this procurer. The procurer has made a determination, from the lowest to the highest, that if each one does not this day send him a present, he shall perish to-morrow with the greatest torments. Now, faith, I know not what to do in my line, for, unless I shall send a present to the procurer this day, to-morrow must I swallow down fullers' produceFullers' produce: As fullers used hands, feet, and sticks is beating the cloth, "fructus fullonius" would mean "kicks and bruises.". And yet I cannot do that which they who can are wont to do. Alas! how little am I, even still for this vocation. And by my troth, now, to my misfortune how fearfully do I dread punishment. If any one lays onIf any one lays on: It is supposed by some that an indecent collusion is obscurely made in this line; it is, however, doubtful if such really is the fact. whose hand is too heavy, although they say that it generally is done amid great weeping, I think that I am able in some measure to keep my teeth closed. But I must keep close my lips and my talking, for see, my master is betaking himself home, and bringing a Cook with him. Stands at a distance.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Those who call it the cook's market, call it so foolishly; for 'tis not a cook's market, but a thieves' market. For if, upon oath, I were to seek out the worst of men, I couldn't have brought a worse one than this fellow that I'm bringing, one, chattering, bragging, silly, and worthless. Why, for this very reason Orcus has declinedOr cus has declined: "Orcus" is an epithet of Pluto, the king of the Infernal regions, and, sometimes, of the place itself. to take him to himself, that he might be here to cook a banquet for the dead; for here he is able to cook a thing to please them alone.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: If you thought of me in this manner that you are mentioning, why did you hire me?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: From scarcity; there wasn't another. But why, if you were a cook, were you sitting in the market-place, you alone behind the rest?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: I'll tell you. By reason of the avarice of men have I become an inferior cook, not through my own inclination.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: For what reason is that?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: I'll tell you. Because, in fact, directly people come to hire a cook, no one enquires for him that's the best and the highest priced: rather do they hire him that's the lowest priced. Through this have I to-day been the only sitter in the market. Those wretched fellows are for a drachma a-piece; not any person is able to prevail on me to rise for less than a didrachmA didrachm: Literally, "nummus," "a coin" or "piece of money," which means a didrachm or piece of two drachmæ in value, or about one shilling and sevenpence of our money.. I don't cook a dinner too, like other cooks, who bring me up seasoned meadows of grass upon their dishes; who turn the guests into oxen, and supply the grass. This herbage, too, do they further season with other herbs: put in coriander, fennel, garlick, orage; they add, too, sorrel, cabbage, beet, and spinach. In this they dissolve a pound weight of asafœtida. The roguish mustard is pounded, which makes the eyes of those that pound it drop tears before they have pounded it. These fellows, when they cook dinners, when they do season them, season them, not with seasonings, but with vampyre owlsWith vampyre owls: "Strigibus." By this expression he probably alludes to the drastic effect of these herbs on those who partook of them. Ovid, in the Sixth Book of the Fasti, has these words: "There are ravenous fowls; not those which used to rob the mouth of Phineus at the board, but thence do they derive their origin. Large are their heads, fixed is their gaze for plunder are their beaks adapted; on their wings is a greyish colour, crooked talons are on their claws. By night they fly, and they seek the children unprotected by the nurse, and pollute their bodies dragged from their cradles. With their beaks they are said to tear the entrails of the sucklings, and they have their maws distended with the blood which they have swallowed. 'Striges' are they called; and the origin of this name is the fact, that they are wont to screech in the dismal night." It is supposed by some persons that, under this name, the vampyre bat is alluded to. which eat out the bowels of the guests while still alive. Through this, in fact, it is, that people here live such short lives, inasmuch as they heap up these herbs of this sort in their stomachs, dreadful to be mentioned, not only to be eaten. Herbage which the cattle eat not, men eat themselves.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: What do you say? Do you use divine seasonings, by which you can prolong the life of men, you, who find fault with these other seasonings?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: I proclaim it boldly; for those who shall eat of my victuals which I have seasoned will be able to exist two hundred years even. For when I've put into the saucepan either cicilendrum, or cepolindrum, or maceCepolindrum, or mace: With the exception of mace, all these names are gibberish, invented by the Cook for the purpose of imposing upon Bailio., or saucaptis, the very dishes become warmed forthwith. These are sauces for fish, the cattle of Neptune; the flesh of the earthly cattle I season with cicimandrum, hapalopsis, or cataractria.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Now may Jupiter and all the Divinities confound you with your sauces, and with all those lies of yours!

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Do allow me to speak, please.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Speak, and go to very perdition.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: When all the saucepans are hot, I open them all then does the odour fly towards heaven with its handhanging downWith its hands hanging down: He means to personify the odour and to represent it as flying up to heaven; but, by mistake, he says it flies up, "demissis manibus," with its hands hanging down, which would father be the attitude of a person thrown out of, and falling from, the heavens. Ballio repeats the expression in a tone of surprise, on which the Cook corrects himself, and says he meant to say, "with its feet hanging down," "demissis pedibus.".

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: The odour with its hands hanging down?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: I made a mistake without thinking.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: With its feet hanging down, I meant to say. Jupiter dines on that odour every day.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: If you happen not to go out to cook, pray what does Jupiter dine upon?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: He goes to sleep without his dinner.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Go to very perdition. Is it for this reason that I'm to give you a didrachm to-day?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Well, I confess that I am a very high-priced cook; but I make the results of my labour to be seen for the price, hired at which I go out.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: In thieving, to wit.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: And do you expect to meet with any cook except with the claws of a kite or of an eagle?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: And do you expect to go anywhere to cook, and not to cook the dinner there with your claws tied up? Now, therefore, you boy to the BOY, who are my servant, I now give you notice to make haste to remove hence all my property; and to keep his eyes as well in your sight. Whichever way he shall look, do you look the same way as well. If he shall move in any direction, do you move as well. If he shall put forth his hand, put you forth your hand as well. If he shall take anything of his own, do you suffer him to take it; if he shall take what's mine, do you on the other side hold him fast. If he shall stoop to the ground, do you stoop there as well. Likewise over your understrappers I shall appoint a single guard a-piece.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Only have good courage.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Prithee, tell me how I possibly can have good courage, who am taking you home to my house?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Because, by my broth, this day will I do just in the way that Medea cooked up the old man PeliasThe old man Pelias: The Cook could not be expected to be very learned in the heathen Mythology; and we accordingly find him making a blunder. Æson, the father of Jason, was restored to youth by the charms of Medea; but Pelias being the enemy of Jason, Medea persuaded his daughters to cut him in pieces, that he might in similar manner restore him to youth; which was accordingly done, on which, having thus contrived his death, she refused her assistance. It is much more probable that the Cook should be intended to be represented as ignorant, than as attempting here to impose on the ignorance of Ballio. Warner, in his translation, however, thinks otherwise. He says, "The humour plainly lies in the Cook's promises to restore Ballio to his juvenility by a cookery--one that would kill him. Ballio's ignorance is, indeed, here meant to be exposed to ridicule by the Cook, that is by Plautus, as it likewise is in the names of the spices, which are probably fictitious." whom she is said by a draught and by her potions from an aged man to have made young again; so will I make you likewise.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: How now; are you an enchanter as well?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Why no, by my troth, I am rather a preserverRather a preserver: The "enchanters," who were called "venefici," "poisoners," were supposed to destroy men by their potions, whence the present reply of the Cook. of mankind.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Well now; for how much would you teach me that one point in cooking?

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: What point?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: That I may preserve you from pilfering anything from me.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: For a didrachm, if you believe me; if not, not for a mina even. But whether are you about to-day to give a dinner, to your friends or to your enemies?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Why, faith, to my friends surely.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: But why don't you invite your enemies to it rather than your friends? For this day will I present to the guests a banquet so savoury, and I'll season it with such a dulcet sweetness, that whoever shall taste each thing that's seasoned, I'll make that same person to gnaw off the ends of his own fingers.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Troth now, prithee, before you shall present aught to the guests do you yourself first taste, and give some to your understrappers, that you may gnaw off the ends of your own pilfering hands.

sp.speaker: A COOK.
sp.p: Perhaps then you don't believe me in the things that I say.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Don't you be troublesome; you din me too much; you don't please me by it. See, there I live. Points to his house. Do you go in-doors and cook the dinner, with all speed.

sp.speaker: A BOY
sp.p: Why don't you go, and take your place? Go and find the guests; the dinner's spoiling already. COOK and BOY go into the house.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Now, just look, please, at that young offshoot; for he, too, is a good-for-nothing deputy-scullion for the cook. Truly I don't know what now first to be on my guard against; such thieves there are in my house, and there's a robber close at hand. For my neighbour here, the father of Calidorus, a short time since, in the market-place, asked me by all means to be on my guard against his servant Pseudolus, not to put any trust in him; for that he is on the hunt this day, if possible to dupe me out of the woman. He said that he had stoutly promised to him that he would get away Phœnicium from me by stratagem. I'll now go indoors and give notice to my household, that no one must put any trust whatever in this Pseudolus. Goes into his house.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p:
If the immortal Gods ever did determine that any person should be assisted by their aid, now do they intend that Calidorus shall be preserved for me, and the procurer destroyed, inasmuch as they produced you for my assistant, so clever and so knowing a fellow. (Looking back.) But where is he? am I not a silly fellow to be thus talking to myself alone? I' faith, he has put a trick upon myself, as I fancy; myself one knave, I have been poorly on my guard against another knave. By my troth I'm undone, if this fellow's off, and I shall not carry into effect this day what I intended. But see, there he is, a statue that deserves a whipping; how stately he does stalk along!
HARPAX.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: How now! By my faith I was looking about for you; I was very greatly afraid that you were off.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: It was my character to do so, I confess.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Where were you loitering?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Where I pleased.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: That I know well enough already.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why then do you ask me what you know?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Why this I want, to put you in mind.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Needing to be put in mind yourself, don't you be putting me in mind.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Really I am treated by you quite with contempt.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: And why shouldn't I treat you with contempt, I who have the repute of being a military gentleman?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: I want this then, which has been commenced, to be completed.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Do you see me a-doing anything else?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Therefore walk on briskly.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: No, I choose to go slowly.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: This is the opportunity; while this Harpax is asleep, I want you to be the first to accost him.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why are you hurrying? Softly; don't you fear. I wish Jupiter would so make it, that he were openly in the same place with me, whoever he is, that has arrived from the Captain. Never a jot, by my troth, should he be a bit the better Harpax than I. Have good courage, I'll have this business nicely accounted for to you. So by my tricks and lies would I put this military stranger in a fright that he himself would deny that he is the person that he is, and would believe me to be the person that he himself is.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: You are murdering me when you ask me that.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: A clever fellow.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: And so are you too, who are quite my equal with your mischievous tricks and lies * * * * * * *

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: May Jupiter preserve you for me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Aye, and for myself. But look, does this dress become me quite well?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: It suits very well.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Be it so.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: May the Deities grant you as many blessings as you may wish for yourself. For if I were to wish for as many as you are deserving of, they would be less than nothing; aside nor have I ever seen any one more of a rogue than this fellow.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: overhearing him. Do you say that to me?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: This man's an honest fellow.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: It is neither this person, then pointing to PSEUDOLUS, nor myself.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: But take care that you don't be tripping.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Can't you hold your tongue? He that puts a man in mind of that which, remembering it, he does keep in mind, causes him to forget it. I recollect everything; they are stored up in my breast; my plans are cleverly laid.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: I'm silent. But what good turn shall I do you if you carry through this matter with management? So may the Gods love me----

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: They won't do so; you'll be uttering sheer falsehoods then.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: How I do love you, Simmia, for your roguery, and both fear and laud you.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: That I have learned to make a present of to others; you can't put your flatteries on me.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: In how delightful a manner I shall receive you this day, when you have completed this matter.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Laughing.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: With nice viands, wine, perfumes, and titbits between our cups. There, too, shall be a charming damsel, who shall give you kiss upon kiss.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: You will be receiving me in a delightful manner.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Aye, and if you effect it, then I'll make you say so still more.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: If I don't effect it, do you, the executioner, take me off to torture. But make haste and point out to me where is the door of the procurer's house.

sp.speaker: PSEUD.
sp.p: 'Tis the third hence.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Hist! hush! the door's opening.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: In my mind, I believe that the house is poorly.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Because, i' faith, it is vomiting forth the procurer. BALLIO is coming out of his house.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Is this he?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: This is his own self.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: 'Tis a worthless commodity.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Do see that: he doesn't go straight, but sideways, just as a crab is wont. They conceal themselves from BALLIO.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I do believe that this fellow is not so bad a cook as I thought he was; for he has clawed off nothing as yet except a cup and a tankard.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: apart to SIMMIA. Hallo you! now's your opportunity and your time.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I agree with you.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Step slily out into the street; I'll be here in ambush. SIMMIA steps forward, and then walks along the middle of the street to meet BALLIO.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: talking aloud to himself. I took the number carefully; this is the sixth lane from the city gate; down that lane he bade me turn; how many houses down he told me, that I don't quite know for certain.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: eyeing SIMMIA. Who's this fellow in the scarf, or whence does he come, or whom is he looking for? The appearance of the fellow seems outlandish and shabby.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: But see, here's a person, who, from uncertainty, will make the thing more certain for me that I wish to know.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: He's coming straight towards me. Where in the world am I to say this fellow comes from?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Harkye! you who are standing there with a goat's beard, answer me this that I ask you.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: How now! Don't you salute me first?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: with a surly voice. I have no salutations to give away.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Well, troth, you shall get just as much from here then.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: from behind. Well done, at the very beginning.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Do you know any person in this lane, I ask you?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I know myself.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Few persons do that which you mention; for in the Forum there is hardly every tenth person that knows his own self.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: from behind. I'm all right; he is philosophizing now.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'm looking for a fellow here, a bad one, a law breaker, an impious, perjured, and dishonest rogue.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: aside. He's looking for me, for those are my titles If he would only mention the name. To SIMMIA. What's the name of this person?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Ballio, the procurer.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Do I know him? I am the very person, young man, that you are looking for.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What, are you Ballio?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I really am he.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: How you are clothed, a housebreaker * * * * * * * * * * He takes hold of BALLIO'S cloak.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I think if you were to see me in the dark, you'd be keeping your hand off.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: My master bade me present you many greetings. Receive this letter from me; he bade me give you it.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Who's the person that bade you?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: from behind. I'm undone, now the fellow's in the middle of the mud. He doesn't know the name--this business is at a dead lock.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Who do you say sent me this?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Observe the seal; do you yourself tell me his name, that I may know that you are Ballio himself.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Give me the letter.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Take it, and look at the seal. Gives him the letter.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: looking at it. Oho! 'Tis nothing more nor less than PolymachæroplagidesPolymachæroplagides: This high-sounding name is compounded of three Greek words, and signifies "the son of many blows with the sword," or something akin to it., his own very self; I recognize it. Hallo you, Polymachæroplagides is his name!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I know now that I have rightly given you the letter, since you have mentioned the name of Polymachæroplagides,

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: How fares he?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: By my troth, just as a brave man and a good soldier should. But make haste, I beg, to read this letter through, for it is requisite to do so, and to take this money at once and send out the damsel. For it's necessary for me this day to be at SicyonTo be at Sicyon: This was a very ancient city of the Peloponnesus on the Gulf of Corinth., or else to suffer death to-morrow; so peremptory is my master.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I know it: you are telling those who know it already.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Make haste then to read the letter through.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I'll do so, if you'll only hold your tongue. He reads the letter. "The Captain Polymachæroplagides sends this letter, written to the procurer Ballio, sealed with the impression which was formerly agreed upon between us two."

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: The token's in the letter

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I see the token and I recognize it. But is he in the habit of sending no greeting written in his letter?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Such is the military etiquette, Ballio; with their hand they send health to their well-wishers, and with the same do they send destruction to their evil-wishers. But as you have commenced, go on to ascertain of yourself what this letter says.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Listen then. Reading on. "Harpax is my camp-servant, who has come to you." Are you this Harpax?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I am, and the real Harpax tooThe real Harpax too: He lays a stress on the name, to catch a laugh from the audience by implying that he is a regular Harpax or "plunderer," both in name and reality..

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: reading on. "Who brings this letter; I wish the money to be received from him, and the woman to be sent together with him. 'Tis becoming to send greeting to the worthy; had I deemed you worthy, I should have sent it to you."

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Pay me the money, take away the woman.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Which of us is delaying the matter?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Follow me in-doors then.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'm following. They go into BALLIO'S house.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: I' troth, a more artful fellow, and one more skilfully cunning, I never did see than is this same Simmia. Very much do I dread this man, and sadly do I fear that he may prove mischievous against myself just as he has been against him; lest in his prosperity he may now turn his horns against me, if he finds an opportunity. Should he prove mischievous towards me * * * * But, i' faith, for my part I hope not, for I wish well to him. Now in three ways am I in the greatest dread. First of all then, I dread this comrade of mine, lest he should forsake me and go over from me to the enemy. Next do I dread that my master should in the meantime return from the Forum; lest, the booty taken, the plunderers should be taken. Together with these things do I fear, lest that other Harpax should arrive here before this Harpax has departed hence with the woman. By my faith, I'm undone; they are very slow in coming out of doors. With baggage packedWith baggage packed: "Conligatis vasis." This is a figure derived from military affairs. In modern as in ancient times, the custom is for the soldiers, when they break up the encampment, to collect all their vessels and baggage and tie them up in bundles. up, my heart is waiting, ready, if he doesn't bring out the damsel together with himself, to fly away in exile out from of my breast. * * * * * * The door of BALLIO'S house opens. I'm the conqueror-- I've got the better of my wary guards.

div2.stage: Enter SIMMIA, from BALLIO'S house, leading PHŒNICIUM.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: to PHŒNICIUM. Don't weep: you know not how the matter is, Phœnicium; but before long I'll let you know it when you are resting. I'm not leading you to that Macedonian long-teethed fellow, who now causes you to be weeping. To him will I lead you, whose you especially long to be. I'll cause you before very long to be embracing Calidorus.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Prithee, why did you stay so long in-doors? For how long a time was my heart throbbing with beating against my breast.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: You have found reason, you whipping-post, with a vengeance to be making enquires of me * * * * * * * amid the ambush of the enemy. Why don't we go home with all speed with military stridesWith military strides: Having often to march quickly, soldiers would naturally acquire the habit of walking with large strides..

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Now, by my troth, although you are a worthless fellow, you advise aright. March in triumphal procession, this way, straight in the path to the festive goblet. They march off in triumphal procession.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! laughing. Now, at last, my mind is in a state of ease, since that fellow has departed hence, and taken away the woman. I should like Pseudolus now to come, that wicked rascal, to carry the woman off from me by his stratagems. I know for sure, right well, that I had rather in solemn form perjure myself a thousand times, than that he should cheat me by making a laughing-stock of me. By my troth now, I'll laugh at the fellow if I meet him. But I guess that he'll soon be on the treadmill, just as befits him. Now I wish for Simo that he would come in my way, in order that he might be joyful in common with my joy.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: to himself. I'm going to see what business my Ulysses has transacted; whether he now has the statueNow has the statue: He alludes to Ulysses carrying away the Palladium or statue of Minerva from the citadel of Troy. from the Ballionian citadel.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: O, lucky man! give me your lucky hand. Takes his hand.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Now.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: There's nothing at all for you to fear.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What's the matter? Has that fellow Pseudolus come to you?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What good fortune is there, then?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Your twenty minæ are safe and sound which Pseudolus stipulated for from you this day.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I' faith, I really do wish they were.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Ask of me twenty minæ if he this day gets hold of that woman, or gives her to your son this day, as he has promised. On my word, prithee, do demand them of me; I quite long to promise them. And, besides this, keep the woman as a present for yourself, that in every way you may know that your money's safe.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: There's no danger that I know of in making this bargain. According as you have solemnly pledged your word, will you give me twenty minæ?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: They shall be given.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: This, indeed, is not sa badly done. But have you met the fellow?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Aye, both of them together.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What did he say? What did ho talk about? Prithee, what did he mention to you?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Theatrical nonsense; expressions which, in comedies, are wont to be used to a procurer, which boys are acquainted with. He said that I was worthless, and wicked, and forsworn.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I' faith, he told no lie.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: 'Twas for that reason I wasn't angry. For what matters it for you to speak uncivilly to him who cares not for it, and who don't deny the truth of what you say?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why is it that you are in no fear of him? That I'm longing to hear.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Because he never will carry the woman off now, nor is he able. Don't you yourself remember that I told you, some time since, that she had been sold to a Macedonian officer?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Well, his servant just now brought me the money, and the token with the impression, which had been arranged between himself and me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: He took away with him the woman, not long since.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Do you say this in real truth?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Whence could I possibly have that quality?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Do you only take care that he hasn't been playing some trick there.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: The letter and the impress on the seal make me sure. Indeed, 'twas but just now he took her off for Sicyon.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Troth now, 'twas well done. Why do I delay to make Pseudolus give a nameGive a name: He alludes to the custom of the first colonists giving the name to a colony. He says that he thinks that he must give Pseudolus settlement at the hand-mill, and so make him colonize the place of punishment. to a colony at the mill-stones? But who's this fellow in the scarf?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I don't know, i' faith; however, let's observe whither he's going, and what business he's upon. They stand on one side.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: to himself. That slave's a base and worthless fellow, who values his master's commands at nought; and he, too, is good for nothing who is forgetful to do his duty unless he's put in mind. But those who forthwith deem themselves to be at liberty, when they have hidden themselves from the sight of their master, who riot, wench, devour what they have,--aye, what they have not,--long do those same endure the name of servitude. Nor is there any good disposition in them, except only that they may uphold themselves by their dishonest contrivances. With these, neither their company nor their conversation suits me, nor by these persons have I been ever known. Although he is away, I consider my master as being here; I fear him when he isn't here, that I may not have to fear him when he is here. Therefore, as I have been ordered, to this business will I give my attention. But that Syrus, to whom I gave the token, would have been letting me stay even yet in the shop. As he bade me, I stayed there; he said that he would send for me when the procurer was at home. But since he hasn't come, or called me while staying there, I'm come hither of my own accord, that I may know what is the fact, that that fellow mayn't be playing tricks with me. And there is nothing better than that I should knock at this door, and call some out here from indoors. I want this procurer to take this money of me, and to send off this woman with me. Goes towards BALLIO'S door.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: from behind, to SIMO. Hark you!

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: apart. What do you want?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: apart. This fellow's my own. SIMO. apart. How so?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: apart, pointing to the purse in the hand of HARPAX. Because that booty's mine. He's in search of a mistress he has got money. I already long to fix my teeth in him.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: apart. Are you going to devour him already?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: apart. While he's fresh, while he's in the habit of giving away, while he's warm upon it, 'tis proper for him to be gobbled up. The good men keep me poor, the bad ones support me; the virtuous are a benefit to the public, the debauched to myself.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: aside. A mischief may the Gods send you; such a villain are you.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: apart. Venus bestows upon me these blessings, when she drives hither these haters of money, these who quite long for losses, who carefully pamper themselves and their youthful age, eat, drink, and wench. Of quite different dispositions are they and you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: to himself. I'm now delaying myself, in not knocking at this door, that I may know whether or no Ballio is at home now. Calls out, going up to the door. Hallo! where are you? Hallo! where are you?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: apart. Why, he's going straight up towards my house. I shall come off finely loaded with plunder from this fellow; I know it's a lucky omen for me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: knocking violently at the door. Does any one come to open this door?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: calling out to him. Hallo! you in the scarf, what's owing you at that house?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I'm enquiring for Ballio, the procurer, the master of the house.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Whoever you are, young man, make short work of your enquiries.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Because he himself in person sees you in his presence before him.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What, are you he?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: You in the scarf, take you care, please, of some crooked misfortune, and point your fingerPoint your finger: Simo thinks that Harpax has come to be a customer of the procurer, and tells him to beware of misfortune, and rather to point the finger of scorn at such a worthless character. The middle finger was used for that purpose. at him; this fellow is a procurer.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: pointing to SIMO. And this is an honest man. To SIMO. But you, worthy fellow, are many a time being hunted after in the Forum with noise enough, when you haven't a groat in the world, unless this procurer here comes to help you a bit.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But why don't you address yourself to me?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I do address you. What is it you want?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You to take this money. He holds out the five minæ.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: holding out his hand. Already have I extended my hand, if you are going to give it.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Take it; here are five picked minæ of silver counted out. Gives him the money. This did my master, Polymachæroplagides. order me to deliver to you, the sum which he was owing, and that you were to send Phœnicium with me.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Your master?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I say to that effect.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: The Captain?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I speak to that effect.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: The Macedonian?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Such is the fact, I say.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Polymachæroplagides sent you to me?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You say what's fact.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: To give me this money?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: If you really are the procurer Ballio.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: And for you to take away the woman from me?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Did he say that it was Phœnicium?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: You remember it exactly.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Wait there; I'll return to you this instant.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Make haste, then, with all speed, for I'm in a hurry. 'Tis now late in the day, d'ye see?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I see; still I wish to call this person aside. Do you only wait there; I'll return to you this instant. He takes SIMO on one side. What's to be done now, Simo? What are we to do? I've detected this fellow that has brought the money in the fact.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: And don't you understand what this plan is?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: About as much as the most ignorant do.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Your servant, Pseudolus, has sent this fellow on the message, as though he was from the Macedonian Captain.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Have you got the money from the fellow?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Do you ask about that which you see? Shows the purse in his hand.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Harkye, remember to give me one half of that plunder. It's right that that should be in common.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Why, plague on't, 'tis all your ownYour own: Meaning that, no doubt, Pseudolus had stolen it from him..

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: coming forward a step. How soon are you going to attend to me?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I'll attend to you, indeed. Aside. What now do you advise me to do, Simo?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: aside. Let's make some fun of this counterfeit spy, even until he himself shall be sensible that he is being made a fool of.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Follow me. To HARPAX. What have you to say? You are his servant, I suppose?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Most certainly.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: At what price did he purchase you?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: With the victory of his prowess in battle; for I was a very great general at home in my own country.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Why, did he ever capture a gaol in your country?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: If you utter affronting speeches, you'll be hearing them.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: In what time did you come from Sicyon hither?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: In one day, by noon.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Bravo! By my troth, you did come quickly; how very swift of foot this man is.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: When you look at his calves, you might know that he can wear heavy fetters. How say you--were you also, when a child, in the habit of sleeping in a cradle?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: And were you, too, in the habit of doingThe habit of doing: An indecent allusion is most probably here intended. An attempt has been made in the translation to turn it into another channel.--you know what I mean?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Of course he was in the habit of doing as other children did?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Are you men in your senses?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: What, because I asked you that? At night, when the Captain was going on guard, and when you were going with him, did the sword of the officer fit your scabbard?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Go to utter perdition.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: You, indeed, shall have the opportunity of going there in good time to-day.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: But do you bring out the woman to me, or else give me back the money.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Wait a bit.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Why should I wait?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: That scarf, tell me for how much it has been lent.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What matters it?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: How much is the sword hired for?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: These fellows surely stand in need of helleboreHave need of hellebore: Black hellebore was much esteemed in eases of madness. Harpax has really, from their way of proceeding, some reason to think that the persons in conversation with him are not in their right senses..

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: How now--Takes hold of him. HAR. repulsing him. Leave me alone.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: What wages does that broad-brimmed hat hire to-day for its owner?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What owner?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What do the shoes? * * * * * * *

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What are you dreaming about? Why, I'm the owner of all these things, bought with my own savings.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Those, you mean, which the upper part of your thighs supportsYour thighs supports: Unless a more gross allusion is intended, he means that his "peculium" is not his "savings" (which is the strict meaning of the word), but his back and flanks, which often receive on them the punishment of servitude, ana which alone he can call his own..

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: aside. These old fellows have been anointed; they want themselves rubbed downThemselves rubbed down: After bathing, the Greeks and Romans were in the habit of being anointed, and then rubbed down with a flesh-brush. Probably the latter custom had gone out of fashion in the time of Plautus. Harpax says that the old men want to be rubbed down; but he means, as uncle Bowling expresses it in Roderick Random, "with an oaken towel.", after the old-fashioned custom.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I' faith, prithee, answer me this truly and seriously, which I ask of you: What are you to earn? For how trifling a sum has Pseudolus hired you?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: Who is this Pseudolus?

sp.speaker: BAR.
sp.p: Your tutor, who has instructed you in this knavery, to take away the woman hence from me by stratagem.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: What Pseudolus, and what stratagem are you talking to me about? A person that I know of no colour, black or white.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Will you not be off from here? There's no profit here for swindlers to-day. Therefore you may tell Pseudolus that another person has carried off the prize-the first Harpax that came.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: On my word, I really am that Harpax.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Aye, on my word, you want to be. This is nothing more nor less than a downright impostor.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I have given yourself the money, and a while ago, immediately on my arrival, the token to your servant; a letter sealed with the likeness of my master, here before the door.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: You gave a letter to my servant? What servant?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: To Syrus.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: to SIMO. The wicked rogue has assurance enoughHas assurance enough: The note of interrogation, in Ritschel's edition, after "nequam," seems to be out of place.. He hasn't contrived his knavish scheme amiss. By my faith, that whipping-post of a fellow, Pseudolus, how cleverly he has managed his plans; just as much money as the Captain owed, he has given this man, and has dressed out the fellow that he might take away the woman * * * * * * * * To HARPAX. But the real Harpax himself brought that letter hither to me.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: My name is Harpax; I am the servant of the Macedonian Captain. I'm doing nothing roguishly or cheatingly, nor do I know or understand this Pseudolus, what mortal being he is.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Unless it's something wonderful, procurer, you've clearly lost the woman.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Assuredly, by my troth, I'm in dread of that more and more, when I come to hear his words. I' faith, that Syrus, too, has already set my heart a-freezing, that received the token from him.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: 'Tis a wonder if it isn't Pseudolus. To HARPAX. How now, you! of what appearance was the person to whom you delivered the token?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: A certain red-haired fellowRed-haired fellow: Some Commentators fancy that in these lines Plautus intends to give a description of himself. If so, he certainly was not so handsome as he was ingenious., pot-bellied, with thick calves, swarthy, with a big head, sharp eyes, red face, and very large feet.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: You prove our undoing, when you mention the feet. It was Pseudolus himself. It's all up with me. I'm dying now, Simo.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: By my troth, I shan't let you die, unless the money's returned me-twenty minæ.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: And another twenty minæ to me as well.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: to SIMO. And is the sum to be taken of me that I promised by way of a joke?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: From unprincipled men it's proper for both their money and their plunder to be taken.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: At least you might give up Pseudolus to me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I, give up Pseudolus to you? What has he done amiss? Did I not tell you a hundred times that you were to beware of him?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: He has ruined me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: And on me he has laid a fine of twenty fair minæ.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: What am I to do then?

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: When you have given me the money--go hang yourself.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: The Gods confound you. To HARPAX. Follow me, then, this way, please, to the Forum, that I may pay you.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: I follow you.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What am I to do?

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: Strangers I'll pay at once; to-morrow I'll settle with fellow-citizens. Pseudolus has been holding a councilgeneralA council-general: "Centuriata habuit comitia." Literally, "has held the comitia centuriata." These were the largest and most important meetings of the centuries or classes of all the Roman citizens, who there met together for the purpose of electing the superior magistrates by their votes, making laws, deciding upon war, and in later times, of concluding peace with foreign nations As these important things were done with due deliberation, Ballio borrows a figure thence, and means that Pseudolus has been giving all attention to the promotion of the success of the plot which he has laid against him. against my life, in sending that fellow to me to-day to carry off the woman. To HARPAX. Do you follow me, To the AUDIENCE. Now don't you be expecting that I shall be returning home this way. As matters stand, I've determined to go through the alleys.

sp.speaker: CHARINUS
sp.p: If you had walked at the rate you talk, you'd by this have been at the Forum.

sp.speaker: BALLIO
sp.p: I'm determined to make this, instead of my birthday, my dying day. (Exit BALLIO, HARPAX following.)

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I've touched this fellow handsomely, and cleverly has my servant managed his adversary. Now am I resolved to lie in ambush for Pseudolus in a different manner to what's done in other plays, where people lie in wait with goads or whips. Without revenge will I at once pay down the twenty minæ which I promised if he should effect it. I'll carry them to him of my own accord. This creature is very clever, very cunning, very artful. Pseudolus has surpassed the Trojan stratagemThe Trojan stratagem: He probably- alludes to the contrivance at the Wooden Horse, which was first suggested by Ulysses and Ulysses too. Now I'll be off in-doors. I'll take out the money; I'll lie in ambush for Pseudolus. Goes into his house.

div2.stage: Enter PSEUDOLUS, drunk, with a chaplet on his head.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: staggering. How's this? And is it the fact? Feet-are you standing or not? Or is it this you want, some; one to pick me up here as I lie? But, by my faith, if I do fall down, yours will be the fault. Are you going to go? Heigho! I must wait upon myself. This is the great fault in wine; it first lays hold of the feet; 'tis a cunning wrestler. By my faith, assuredly am I now come off right well drenched; with such exquisite viands, with such becoming elegance, in such a delightful place, have we been delightfully entertained. What's the need for me to make much prosing? This is the thing for a man, an object for him to pass his life for; here are all pleasures and all delights. I think that the ecstasy is equal to that of the Deities, when the lover embraces his mistress, when he places lip to lip, when melting kisses are exchanged, when breast is pressed to breast, or else, if they please, they are locked in strict embrace; then for your most loving mistress, with her white hand, to be pledging you in the luscious goblet, for no one there to be disagreable to another, for no one to be indulging in silly conversation; for unguents and perfumes, ribbonsRibbons: "Lemniscos." According to Festus, "lemnisci" were purple ribbons wrapped round one another, and hanging down from the wreaths which the ancients wore on their heads at their entertainments. From a passage in Pliny it would appear that these ribbons were in general only worn by persons of distinction. The translation of l. 1260 has necessarily been somewhat modified. and festive wreaths, to be provided in profusion; and for the rest of the entertainment, too, to be provided in no niggardly style. That no one may have to question me then, in this manner have myself and my young master been spending this day in jollity. After I had fulfilled all my task just as I intended, the enemy put to flight, I was leaving them reclining and drinking, each lover with his mistress, and my own mistress there as well, indulging heart and soul. But after I had risen, they begged me to dance. After this fashion he dances did I show myself off there quite charmingly, in a master-like style, to wit; for I am thoroughly acquainted with the Ionian step. Thus, clad in my little mantle, full of fun, I was stepping about, this way. Some of them clapped me, others cried out for me to dance again. In that same Ionian fashion once again did I begin to take a turn; I presented myself to my mistress, that she might caress me; as I was pirouetting, down I tumbled: that was the funeral dirgeThe funeral dirge: The word "Nænia," or "nenia," has severai meanings, among others, that of "a funeral dirge," which is probably its meaning here. Pseudolus intends to say that his fall, so far as he was concerned, put an and to his enjoying the amusement of dancing any further. for my sport. And so, while I was a-struggling to get up, near----, almost, I mean, I soiled my mantle. Then, by my troth, I was the cause of plenteous mirth. A goblet was presented me on account of my fall. Forthwith I changed my mantle, and put on this; thence have I come hither, that I might get rid of my surfeit. Now I'm going to my old master, to put him in mind of our bargain. Open-open the door. Hallo, there! Tell Simo, somebody, that I'm here. Knocks at the door of SIMO'S house.

div2.stage: Enter SIMOAll the former editions introduced Ballio in this scene, and put in his mouth much of what really belongs to Simo. The astute Ritschel saw the absurdity of this, and has rectified the text accordingly., from his house.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: The voice of a rascally fellow is calling me out of doors. He stares at PSEUDOLUS. But what's this? How's this? What is it I see in this guise?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: staggering towards him. Your own Pseudolus, drunk, with a chaplet onWith a chaplet on: Pseudolus lays some stress on this, as slaves were not permitted to wear chaplets. He, however, presumes on the fact of Simo being in his debt..

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: to himself. By my troth, this is free and easy indeed. But see his attitude; is he on my account a bit the more afraid? I'm thinking whether I shall address him harshly or kindly. But this pointing to a purse in his hand that I'm carrying forbids me to use rough measures towards him just now; if there's any hope for me, centred in this.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: staggering up to SIMO. A worthless fellow is coming to meet the best of men.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: May the Gods bless you, Pseudolus. PSEUDOLUS eructates. Foh! go to utter perdition. Pushes him away.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: But why should I have that mischance befal me?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why, the plague, in your drunkenness, are you eructating in my face?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Hold me up, steadily; take care that I don't fall. Don't you see me, how drenched and soaking I am?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What impudence is this, for you to be going about this way in broad daylight, drunk, with a chaplet on?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Such is my pleasure. Eructates again. SIMO. Why your pleasure? Do you persist in eructating in my very face?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: An eructation is comforting to me; do indulge me in it; do but stand off.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: For my part I really do believe, you villain, that you are able in a single hour to drink up four right plentiful vintages of the Massic hillsThe Massic hills: The Massic hills were situate in the Falernian district, in the territory of Naples. The Massic or Falernian wine held the second rank among the choice wines of the Romans. It was considered fit for drinking when ten years old, and might be used up to the twentieth year, but when kept anger was considered to be injurious to the nervous system..

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: A winter hourA winter hour: The Romans divided the light part of the day. into twelve hours; consequently, the hours of the winter days were much shorter than the summer ones., add.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: You don't remind me amiss. But tell me, however, whence I am to say that you are bringing your deeply-laden bark?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: I've just been having a thorough bout with your son. That damsel is the cause of this; along with your son she is carousing, a free woman.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: You are a most worthless fellow.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: But, Simo, wasn't Ballio nicely diddled? How well I carried what I told you into effect.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I know everything in its order, just as you managed each particular.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Why, then, do you hesitate to pay me the money?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: You ask what's just, I confess; take it. Gives him the money.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: But you declared that you wouldn't give it me; and still do you give it.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Are you laughing at me? What? Are you going to take this from your master, Pseudolus?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: With most willing heart and soul.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Prithee, can't you venture to make me an abatement of some portion of this money?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: No: you shall say that I really am a greedy fellow; for you shall never be richer by a single coin of this money.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Well, I really didn't suppose that it would ever come to pass with me that I should be begging of you.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Load your shoulder with it, and follow me this way. Pointing.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I--load myself with that?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: You will load yourself, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What am I to do to this fellow? Doesn't he, contrary to my expectation, take my money, and then laugh at me?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Woe to the conqueredWoe to the conquered: The following was the origin of this expression. When the Romans capitulated to the Gauls under Brennus, a thousand pounds weight of gold were to be their ransom. When it was about to be weighed out, the Gauls brought false weights. On this the Roman officer refused to use them, whereupon Brennus threw his sword into the scale, and exclaimed "Væ victis!" "Woe to the conquered!" The expression afterwards became proverbial, as signifying that no mercy was to be expected.: turn your back, then. Turns him round.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Oh! oh! desist. Let me alone--I'm in pain.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Were you not in pain, I should be in pain; and no compassion would you have had for my back, if I hadn't this day managed this.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: There will be an opportunity for me to be revenged on you, if I live.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Why do you threaten? I've got a back of my own.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Very well, then. Moves as if going. PSEUD. Come you back then.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Why come back?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Only come you back; you shall not be deceived.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: turns round. I am come back. PSEUD. Come and have a drink with me.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: What--I, come?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: Do as I ask you. If you do come, I'll let you take half of this, or even more. Points to the purse in his hand.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I'll come; take me where you like, Pseudolus.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: How now then? Are you at all angry with me or with your son, Simo, on account of these matters?

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: Certainly, not at all.

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: going. Step this way now.

sp.speaker: SIMO
sp.p: I follow you. But why don't you invite the Spectators as well?

sp.speaker: PSEUDOLUS
sp.p: turning round. I' faith, they are not in the habit of inviting me; and, therefore, I don't invite them. But if you addressing the AUDIENCE are willing to applaud and approve of this company of players, and this Comedy, I invite you for to-morrowInvite you for to-morrow: At the Megalensian games the third day was especially set apart for scenic representations. Probably, as the present Play was acted there, it was on that occasion announced for repetition on the succeeding day. It may not be inapposite here to remark that Cicero, in his Treatise on Old Age, informs us that Plautus entertained a very high opinion of this Play; while Aulus Gellius styles it "Comœdia festissima," "a most entertaining Comedy." Many of the modern Commentators have pronounced it to be the most meitorious of the Plays of Plautus..
